From their heretical research, they've come to believe such otherworldly beings are two sides of the same divine kin.
Daemonology is rarely practiced. If the nature of their abilities is discovered, they risk being persecuted not only by superstitious folk but also by celestial and infernal powers.

subclassFeature.name: Fair and Foul
entries: The spells listed below can be added to your spellbook for no cost when you reach the associated level.

Each time you finish a Long Rest, choose whether you are siphoning power from Arch Daemons or Arch Seraphs. You can prepare the spells listed for your Wizard level and lower, but not those from the opposite faction.

subclassFeature.name: Stolen Secrets
entries: You have uncovered or stolen secret power from agents of the Arch Daemons and Arch Seraphs. You gain one Eldritch Invocation of your choice.

entries.name: Prerequisites
entries: If an invocation has a prerequisite, you must meet it to learn that invocation. If an invocation has a Warlock level prerequisite, you use your Wizard level instead. For example, if an invocation requires you to be a level 5+ Warlock, you can select the invocation once you reach Wizard level 5.

entries.name: Replacing and Gaining Invocations
entries: Whenever you gain a Wizard level, you can replace one of your invocations with another one for which you qualify. You can't replace an invocation if it's a prerequisite for another invocation that you have.
You gain an additional invocation when you reach Wizard levels 6 and 14.
You can't pick the same invocation more than once unless its description says otherwise.

entries.name: Intelligent Invocations
entries: You can use your Intelligence modifier instead of your Charisma modifier for your invocations.

subclassFeature.name: Borrowed Tongues and Hides
entries: Your ability to siphon power from Celestials and Fiends is enhanced. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Arch Daemon Boon
entries: While you are siphoning power from Arch Daemons, you have {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} to Necrotic damage. In addition, Fiends that know languages can understand your speech and you can understand theirs, even if you do not share a language.

entries.name: Arch Seraph Boon
entries: While you are siphoning power from Arch Seraphs, you have {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} to Radiant damage. In addition, Celestials that know languages can understand your speech and you can understand theirs, even if you do not share a language.

entries.name: Switch Sides
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can change which power you are siphoning from. Once you switch, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Unearthly Countenance
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you adopt an infernal or celestial countenance for 10 minutes. For the duration, your appearance gains aspects of the power you choose. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Commanding Presence
entries: You have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Charisma checks.

entries.name: Improved Spells
entries: When you expend a spell slot to cast a spell from the Arch Daemon or Arch Seraph table, the spell is cast as if you had spent a spell slot of one level higher.

entries.name: Unearthly Wings
entries: You gain a {@variantrule Fly Speed|XPHB} of 60 feet.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can also restore your use of it by expending a level 5+ spell slot (no action required).

subclassFeature.name: Eternal War Eruption
entries: You use the powers at your command to call forth warring celestials and infernals. As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, you summon a manifestation of the war between Arch Daemons and Arch Seraphs in a 30-foot-radius {@variantrule Sphere [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Sphere} centered on a point within 120 feet of yourself.

Each creature in the {@variantrule Sphere [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Sphere} must make a Charisma saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, a creature takes {@damage 4d10} Necrotic damage, {@damage 4d10} Radiant damage, and has the {@condition Blinded|XPHB} condition until the end of its next turn. On a successful save, a creature takes half as much damage only.
As part of the same action, you can change the power you are siphoning from, and you also regain 1 Wizard spell slot of your choice of 5th level or lower.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Highway Rider
entries: {@i A Steed Makes the Best Partner in Crime}

Stalking the backroads, the Highway Rider strikes fear into the heart of every traveler and penny-pinching merchant. They run down their prize astride a swift and loyal steed—and then make a quick getaway.

subclassFeature.name: Hair Trigger
entries: You gain proficiency with Blackpowder Pistols. In addition, when you roll {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} and don't have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on that roll, you can immediately take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} for one of the following options:

items: Make one attack with a weapon or {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB}.
Move up to your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} without provoking {@action Opportunity Attack|XPHB|Opportunity Attacks}.
A controlled mount moves up to its {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} without provoking {@action Opportunity Attack|XPHB|Opportunity Attacks}.
Take the {@action Dodge|XPHB} or {@action Utilize|XPHB} action.

subclassFeature.name: Trusty Mount
entries: You always have the {@spell Find Steed|XPHB} spell prepared. With this feature, you can cast it without a spell slot or components, and your spellcasting ability for it is Intelligence.
Once you cast the spell with this feature, you can't do so in this way again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Ride Them Down
entries: You don't need {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on the attack roll to Sneak Attack if you or a controlled mount you ride moves at least 20 feet, and you don't have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on the attack roll.

subclassFeature.name: Horse Lord
entries: You can spend 1 minute grooming and caring for your mount, at the end of which it gains a number of {@variantrule Temporary Hit Points|XPHB} equal to twice your Rogue level.

In addition, your cunning extends to your steed. While you control a mount, it can take one of the following actions as a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}: {@action Dash|XPHB}, {@action Disengage|XPHB}, or {@action Dodge|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: True Grit
entries: You gain proficiency in Constitution saving throws. In addition, when you are subjected to an effect that allows you to make a Constitution saving throw to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed on the saving throw, and only half damage if you fail.

subclassFeature.name: Desperado
entries: When you are reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} and not killed outright, you can use your Hair Trigger feature immediately before you fall {@condition Unconscious|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Misfortune Bringer
entries: {@i Curse Those You're About to Strike}

You've matched your penchant for illicit activities with the ability to mark your enemies for mishap and misfortune. Whether you were imbued with magic by spending time among the Fey or you learned the art of cursing from a long line of hedge Wizards, you are a Misfortune Bringer. Although not universal, many Misfortune Bringers possess heterochromia iridumeyes of two different colorsand they use only one when glaring at targets they intend to curse.

subclassFeature.name: Evil Eye
entries: You can place a minor curse with a glance. As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, choose a creature you can see within 60 feet of yourself to be cursed by your Evil Eye. While a creature is cursed by your Evil Eye, you can deal Sneak Attack damage to the creature if you don't have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on the attack roll.
The creature remains cursed by your Evil Eye for 1 minute or until you curse a different creature with your Evil Eye, whichever comes first.

subclassFeature.name: Misfortunist
entries: You learn Misfortunes that you can inflict on those cursed by your Evil Eye.

entries.name: Misfortunes
entries: You learn two Misfortunes of your choice, which are detailed under {@filter "Misfortunes"|optionalfeatures|source=GrimHollowPG24|feature type=mb:m} below.

You learn an additional Misfortune of your choice when you reach Rogue levels 9, 13, and 17. When you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, you can replace one Misfortune you know with a different one.

entries.name: Jinx Points
entries: You have 4 Jinx Points. You gain 2 additional Jinx Points at Rogue level 13. To use a Misfortune option, you must spend the number of Jinx Points that it costs.
You regain all expended Jinx Points when you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Saving Throws
entries: If a Misfortune requires a saving throw, the DC equals 8 + your Charisma or Intelligence modifier (your choice) + your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}.

subclassFeature.name: Steal Luck
entries: When a creature you can see within 30 feet of yourself is about to make a {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB} with {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB}, you can take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to prevent the roll from being affected by {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB}. When you do so, you regain 1 expended Jinx Point.
Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Curse Caster
entries: You can take a {@action Magic|XPHB} action and spend 3 Jinx Points to cast {@spell Bestow Curse|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Steal Luck
entries: You can use your Steal Luck feature three times, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Sanguine Thief
entries: {@i Eliminate Your Prey with Blood Magic}

In dark alleyways across Etharis, deals are made in coin and blood, but a few enterprising Rogues have posed the question: Why not both? Sanguine Thieves are assassins who harness the power of Sangromancy to fuel their abilities, finding new and innovative ways to utilize the blood they see all too frequently in their line of work.

Sanguine Thieves learn to draw upon the vitae of their victims, extending their ability to use blood magic beyond the limits of their own vitality. When cornered, Sanguine Thieves can unleash this power in a hail of crimson darts or fade before a foe's blade, leaving nothing behind but a red mist.

subclassFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: You have learned to cast Wizard spells, as well as spells from the Sangromancy school. All Sangromancy spells and cantrips are treated as Wizard spells for the purposes of this subclass.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: You know three cantrips from the Wizard spell list and from the list of Sangromancy spells. Whenever you gain a Rogue level, you can replace one of your cantrips with another Wizard cantrip of your choice.
When you reach Rogue level 10, you learn another Wizard cantrip of your choice.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Sanguine Thief Spellcasting table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your level 1+ spells. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Prepared Spells of Level 1+
entries: You prepare the list of level 1+ spells that are available for you to cast with this feature. To start, choose three level 1 Wizard spells.

The number of spells on your list increases as you gain Rogue levels, as shown in the Prepared Spells column of the Sanguine Thief Spellcasting table. Whenever that number increases, choose additional Wizard spells until the number of spells on your list matches the number in the Sanguine Thief Spellcasting table. The chosen spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

entries.name: Changing Your Prepared Spells
entries: Whenever you gain a Rogue level, you can replace one spell on your list with another Wizard spell for which you have spell slots.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for your Wizard spells.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use an Arcane Focus as a {@variantrule Spellcasting Focus|XPHB} for your Wizard spells.

subclassFeature.name: Stolen Power
entries: You draw magic from blood. It is represented by your Sangromancy Dice, which fuel powers you have from this subclass. You have a pool of d8s that you can use on Sanguine Thief features. The number of damage dice in the pool equals the number of damage dice as shown in the Sneak Attack column of the Rogue Features table. You can't have more Sangromancy Dice than the number of damage dice shown in the Sneak Attack column for your level, unless you have Sangromancy Dice from a different source.

entries.name: Blood Magic
entries: You can spend Sangromancy Dice instead of {@variantrule Hit Point Dice|XPHB|Hit Dice} when you cast Sangromancy spells.
Your pool regains all expended dice when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Steal Blood
entries: When you deal Sneak Attack damage, you can restore 1 Sangromancy Die.

If you are {@variantrule Bloodied|XPHB}, instead of restoring 1 Sangromancy Die when you deal Sneak Attack damage, you can immediately roll the die and regain a number of {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} equal to the roll's total.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Bloody Blades
entries: When you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, you can spend up to 2 {@variantrule Hit Point Dice|XPHB|Hit Dice} or Sangromancy Dice to create a number of Daggers equal to the number of dice spent in this way. Each Dagger counts as an Arcane Focus for your Sanguine Thief spells, and you can cast spells with Somatic components even if you wield these weapons in one or both hands.

Additionally, when you score a {@variantrule Critical Hit|XPHB} with this weapon, you can cause the weapon to deal extra damage to the target. The extra damage is a number of d8s equal to the number of {@variantrule Hit Point Dice|XPHB|Hit Dice} or Sangromancy Dice spent on this feature. The extra damage is Necrotic.
The Daggers lasts until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Bloodstitch
entries: As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, you can spend 3 {@variantrule Hit Point Dice|XPHB|Hit Dice} or Sangromancy Dice to fling a wave of needle-like blood shards. When you do so, each creature of your choice in a 30-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} originating from you must make a Dexterity saving throw against your spell save DC, taking {@damage 3d8} Necrotic damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one. You regain 1 {@variantrule Hit Point Dice|XPHB|Hit Die} or Sangromancy Die (your choice) for each creature reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} by this feature.
Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Bloody Exit
entries: When a creature hits you with an attack roll, you can take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} and spend 5 {@variantrule Hit Point Dice|XPHB|Hit Dice} or Sangromancy Dice to turn into bloody mist. The attack automatically misses you, you can teleport up to 30 feet to an unoccupied space you can see, and you regain your normal form. As part of this {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB}, you can make an attack with a Melee weapon immediately after you teleport. On a hit, this attack deals an extra {@damage 5d8} Necrotic damage to the target.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Primordial Archer
entries: {@i Channel the Wrath of the Wilds}

In the areas of Etharis where nature still holds sway, many cling to the ancient customs of woodland hunters and witches. Marking themselves with wild plants and bone needles, theirs is a tradition of cunning, cruelty, and reprisal against all trespassers. Unlike the Druids, these wood witches twist natural magic into hexes, imbuing their weapons with nature's fury.

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Arrows
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can imbue a {@item Longbow|XPHB} or {@item Shortbow|XPHB} with elemental energy for 1 minute. Choose one of the following damage types: Acid, Cold, Fire, Lightning, or Thunder. For the duration, the imbued weapon deals damage of the selected type instead of its normal type and deals an extra {@damage 1d6} damage of the chosen type when it hits. At the start of each of your turns, you can change this choice.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Herbal Lore
entries: You gain an {@item Herbalism Kit|XPHB} and are proficient with it. You can use the {@item Herbalism Kit|XPHB} as a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to stabilize an {@condition Unconscious|XPHB} creature within 5 feet of you that has 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} as if using a Healer's Kit without needing to make a Wisdom ({@skill Medicine|XPHB}) check. If you take a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action, an {@condition Unconscious|XPHB} creature within 5 feet of you that has 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} gains 1 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB|Hit Point} instead.
Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Primordial Archer Spells
entries: When you reach a Ranger level specified in the Primordial Archer Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

subclassFeature.name: Weave the Elements
entries: With 1 hour of work or when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, you can use an {@item Herbalism Kit|XPHB} to mark yourself with elemental patterns. You gain {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} to one of the following damage types of your choice until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}: Acid, Cold, Fire, Lightning, or Thunder.

subclassFeature.name: Witching Arrows
entries: You gain the ability to imbue curses into your arrows. Once per turn when you hit a creature with a ranged attack using a {@item Longbow|XPHB} or {@item Shortbow|XPHB}, you can expend a level 1+ spell slot to choose one of the following effects (no action required). The listed damage increases by {@dice 2d6} for each spell slot above 1.

entries.name: Arcing Shot
entries: Electricity crackles around the arrow. Make a ranged attack roll with the same weapon against a second creature within 30 feet of the first that is also within your range. Each creature hit takes {@damage 2d6} Lightning damage.

entries.name: Entangling Shot
entries: The wooden shaft of the arrow sprouts tiny green leaves. The target must succeed on a Strength saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, the target takes {@damage 2d6} Piercing damage and has the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition for 1 minute. On a successful save, the creature takes the damage only. A {@condition Restrained|XPHB} creature repeats the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

entries.name: Hexing Shot
entries: The magic surrounding your arrow clouds the mind of your target. The target must make a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, the target takes {@damage 2d6} Psychic damage and gains the {@condition Charmed|XPHB} or {@condition Frightened|XPHB} condition for 1 minute (your choice). The creature can repeat the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage only.

entries.name: Viper Shot
entries: The arrow transforms into a hissing serpent. The target must make a Constitution saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, the target takes {@damage 2d6} Poison damage and has the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition for 1 minute. The creature can repeat the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage only.

subclassFeature.name: Primordial Magic
entries: Taking damage can't break your {@status Concentration|XPHB} on any Ranger spells you cast.

In addition, you can take a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to change the damage type you chose for the Weave the Elements feature to a different damage type in the list. When you do, you can choose a creature that you can see within 30 feet of yourself. That creature must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or take {@damage 6d6} damage of the either damage type (your choice).
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Vermin Lord
entries: {@i Grow Powerful from Strength in Numbers}

Vermin Lords cultivate loyal hordes of disease-bearing rodents to help them battle greater evils. For many of these Rangers, that greater evil is some kind of societal ill, but a rare few see their fellow Humanoids as an infestation that threatens the natural world. Regardless of their goal, they make their homes in sewers, slums, and other forgotten places where they are free to plot against their enemies and tend to their verminkin.

subclassFeature.name: Verminkin
entries: You can comprehend and verbally communicate with Tiny Beasts.

As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, you can expend a spell slot to summon vermin swarms. You summon a number of swarms equal to the slot's level for 1 hour. Each swarm is summoned to an unoccupied space you can see within 30 feet of yourself. A swarm uses the {@creature Swarm of Vermin|GrimHollowPG24} stat block.

In combat, each swarm acts during your turn. It can move and use its {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} on its own, but the only action it takes is the {@action Dodge|XPHB} action unless you take a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to command it to take an action in its stat block or some other action. You can command each swarm with a single {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Swarming Strikes
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can command all of your swarms to make an {@action Attack|XPHB} action instead of just one. Alternatively, a single swarm can attack twice instead of once when it takes the {@action Attack|XPHB} action.

You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier plus your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Vermin Lord Spells
entries: When you reach a Ranger level specified in the Vermin Lord Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

subclassFeature.name: Filth and Fortitude
entries: The time you've spent with plague-bearing rodents has rendered you {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immune} to the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} conditions. Additionally, you gain proficiency in Constitution saving throws.

subclassFeature.name: Infectious Spread
entries: When you use Swarming Strikes, each swarm that takes the {@action Attack|XPHB} action makes one additional attack. Each creature damaged by a swarm's attack during this action has the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition until the start of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Strength of the Swarm
entries: You can call on your rodent minions for defense. When you take damage from a creature you can see within 10 feet of yourself, you can take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to direct the damage toward a swarm you control you can see within 5 feet of yourself.

subclassFeature.name: Green Reaper
entries: {@i Slay with Nature's Venom}

Green Reapers are assassins who specialize in harnessing the toxic elements of flora and fauna. These Rangers often work as killers for hire utilizing their extensive knowledge to end lives discreetly or with gory panache, depending on the poison used and the client's wishes. Green Reapers exhibit a morbid curiosity when encountering a toxin they're unfamiliar with, typically followed by an enthusiastic application of the substance on their next foe.

subclassFeature.name: Envenomed Attack
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can apply a poison dose to a weapon or up to 20 pieces of ammunition. Once applied, the poison retains its potency for 1 minute. Your attacks with the {@condition poisoned} item deal an extra {@damage 1d4} Poison damage on a hit.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.
At Ranger level 11, the extra Poison damage increases to {@dice 2d4}, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Toxic Tradecraft
entries: You gain a {@item Poisoner's Kit|XPHB}, and you have proficiency with it. In addition, your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus} is doubled for ability checks with a {@item Poisoner's Kit|XPHB}. If you lose the kit, you can harvest toxic flora and venomous fauna for 1 hour to magically create a replacement. This harvest can be performed during a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, and it destroys the previous {@item Poisoner's Kit|XPHB}.

Once per turn when you deal Poison damage to a creature with a weapon attack, you can expend a spell slot (no action required). The attack deals an extra {@damage 1d6} Poison damage and the target gains the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition until the end of your next turn. You may also add a Toxin Effect, chosen from the appropriate list below. All Toxin Effects last until the end of your next turn, unless its description states otherwise.

entries.name: Level 1 Spell Slot Effects
entries: When you expend a level 1+ spell slot, choose one of the following effects to add to the toxin.

entries.name: Attenuate
entries: While a creature has the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition from this toxin, it has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on Strength and Dexterity saving throws.

entries.name: Befuddled
entries: While a creature has the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition from this toxin, it can't speak, read, or write and it has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on saving throws made to maintain {@status Concentration|XPHB} on spells.

entries.name: Uncoordinated
entries: While a creature has the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition from this toxin, it can't take {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB|Reactions} or the {@action Disengage|XPHB} or {@action Dodge|XPHB} action.

entries.name: Level 2 Spell Slot Effects
entries: When you expend a level 2+ spell slot, choose one of the following effects to add to the toxin.

entries.name: Debilitate
entries: For 1 minute, the creature can't regain {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}.

entries.name: Potent
entries: For 1 minute, the creature loses {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} to Poison damage.

entries.name: Suffer
entries: For 1 minute, the first time on each turn the creature takes Poison damage, it takes an extra {@damage 1d6} Poison damage.

entries.name: Level 3 Spell Slot Effects
entries: When you expend a level 3+ spell slot, choose one of the following effects to add to the toxin.

entries.name: Lingering
entries: Instead of ending at the end of your next turn, the creature has the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition for 10 minutes. During this time it has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on saving throws to end the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition on itself. At the end of each of the creature's turns, it can make a Constitution saving throw to end the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition.

entries.name: Supernatural
entries: When you deal damage to a creature with a {@condition poisoned} item, the creature loses {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition and then has the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition for 1 minute. At the end of each of the creature's turns, it can make a Constitution saving throw to end the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition and regain its {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition.

entries.name: Level 4 Spell Slot Effects
entries: When you expend a level 4+ spell slot, choose one of the following effects to add to the toxin.

entries.name: Flesh Eating
entries: For 1 minute, the creature has the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition. While a creature has the Posioned condition from this toxin, it takes {@damage 2d6} Acid damage at the start of each of its turns.

entries.name: Insensate
entries: While a creature has the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition from this toxin, it also has the {@condition Blinded|XPHB} and {@condition Deafened|XPHB} conditions.

entries.name: Paraplegia
entries: While a creature has the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition from this toxin, its {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} is reduced to 0 and it has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on Dexterity saving throws.

entries.name: Level 5 Spell Slot Effects
entries: When you expend a level 5 spell slot, choose one of the following effects to add to the toxin.

entries.name: Enhanced
entries: Apply one option from the Level 4 Spell Slot Effects list, and an additional option from either the Level 1 or Level 2 Spell Slot Effects list.

entries.name: Stinging Application
entries: For 1 minute, once per turn, when you hit a creature with a {@condition poisoned} item, the attack deals an extra {@damage 5d6} damage. The damage type is your choice of Acid, Necrotic, or Poison.

subclassFeature.name: Green Reaper Spells
entries: When you reach a Ranger level specified in the Green Reaper Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed spells prepared.

subclassFeature.name: Poison Control
entries: You gain {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} to Poison damage and have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws to avoid or end the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition.

In addition, you can cast the {@spell Protection from Poison|XPHB} spell without expending a spell slot. You can do so a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Variegated Vexations
entries: Whenever you would deal Poison damage with a weapon attack, you can change that damage to be either Acid or Necrotic instead.

subclassFeature.name: Pain Tolerance
entries: You have learned to quickly inure yourself against harm. Immediately before you take damage from a creature you can see within 60 feet of yourself, you can take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to gain {@variantrule Temporary Hit Points|XPHB} equal to the damage you take. If any of these {@variantrule Temporary Hit Points|XPHB} remain at the end of your next turn, they vanish.

subclassFeature.name: Carver Guild
entries: {@i Slay Monsters Fearlessly and Recklessly}

Since the beginning of time, the brave glared into danger's ferocious eyes and fought monsters. Those who survived were the ones smart enough to arm themselves properly and know precisely where to strike—or those who knew when to flee and return with a new plan.

Members of the Carver Guild are the Monster Hunters typically called upon when immediate danger threatens a settlement and there is no army or militia available. Carvers stride unflinchingly toward death, armed with years of training and the knowledge passed down from those before them.

subclassFeature.name: Equipped for Battle
entries: You gain training with Heavy armor.

subclassFeature.name: Close Quarters
entries: Your skill in close combat enables you to inflict crushing blows while keeping your opponent off balance. When you hit a creature with an attack roll using a Melee weapon, you can take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to deal an extra {@damage 1d6} damage of the same type dealt by the weapon. That creature has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on its next attack roll before the start of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: True Grit
entries: You have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws you make to avoid or end the {@condition Frightened|XPHB} condition, and you are {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immune} to the {@condition Frightened|XPHB} condition caused by creature types in your Monster Grimoire.

Additionally, when you hit a creature with an attack as part of a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB}, you can choose a {@condition Frightened|XPHB} creature within 60 feet that can see you (including yourself). The condition ends on that creature.

subclassFeature.name: Terrorize the Terrors
entries: Your reputation has become such that monsters preying on the fearful have come to fear you. When you hit a creature with an attack as part of a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB}, you can force the creature to make a Wisdom saving throw or have the {@condition Frightened|XPHB} condition until the end of your next turn. The DC for the saving throw equals 8 plus your Intelligence modifier and your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}.

subclassFeature.name: Deadly Redirect
entries: Your strikes have become even deadlier. The extra damage of your Close Quarters increases to {@dice 3d6}. In addition, if you deal damage to a creature with Close Quarters, the target has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on all attack rolls until the end of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Controlled Footwork
entries: You are such an effective combatant that you are always in control and never off balance. You can take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} twice in a round instead of once.

subclassFeature.name: Devourer Guild
entries: {@i Gain Power by Consuming Monster Flesh}

Folk in Etharis don't always speak highly of Monster Hunters, and many consider them to be just as depraved and inhuman as the evils they vanquish. Many of the appalling tales about Monster Hunters can be attributed, directly or indirectly, to the Devourer Guild, who are accused of being monstrous cannibals.

The truth is barely any better. Devourers have spent their days consuming the flesh and blood of the monsters they slay, and, over time, their metabolism has changed to tolerate this disgusting practice. Devourers adopt mutations shortly after consuming their prey.

subclassFeature.name: Alchemical Gastronomy
entries: You gain proficiency with {@item Alchemist's Supplies|XPHB} and {@item Cook's Utensils|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Transmuting Metabolism
entries: You gain the ability to consume monster remains, which causes your body to adopt powerful and frightening mutations. These appear in the "Mutations" section later in the subclass's description.

entries.name: Salvaging Portions
entries: As a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action, you can harvest a single portion from the physical remains of a creature. Only one portion can be harvested from each creature. Record the monster's creature type. A harvested portion lasts until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, at which point it loses its potency.

entries.name: Consuming Portions
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can consume a portion. After you consume the portion, you choose a mutation to gain, depending on the creature's type. You can gain the benefits of consumed portions a number of times up to 1 plus your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1). When you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, you regain the ability to safely consume portions.
You can benefit from multiple portions simultaneously, but you can't gain the same mutation more than once at the same time.

subclassFeature.name: Synchronized Response
entries: Your ingestion of monsters heightens your understanding of them and their behaviour. You gain this additional effect when you consume a monster portion: For 1 minute, when you make an attack as part of a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB}, you deal an extra {@damage 1d6} damage. This damage has the same type as the weapon or {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB} used for the attack.

subclassFeature.name: Gnawing Hunger
entries: Your hunger for your enemy allows you to partake of its essence during battle. When you deal damage to a creature with a melee attack using a weapon or {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB}, you gain {@variantrule Temporary Hit Points|XPHB} equal to half the damage dealt. If the target is a creature type in your Monster Grimoire, you instead gain {@variantrule Temporary Hit Points|XPHB} equal to the damage dealt instead.

You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Alchemical Decoctions
entries: You can spend 1 hour and 20 GP worth of alchemical ingredients (such as special herbs or monster salvage) to use your {@item Alchemist's Supplies|XPHB} to convert a monster portion into a decoction. A decoction is a magic potion that grants the benefits of a consumed monster portion. You can have 4 unconsumed decoctions active. You can destroy a decoction as a {@action Utilize|XPHB} action.

A creature other than you can consume 1 decoction without adverse effects. A creature gains 1 {@condition Exhaustion|XPHB} level for each decoction it consumes after the first. A creature must finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} before it regains the ability to safely consume a decoction.

subclassFeature.name: Acquired Taste
entries: Your hunger for monster portions has increased to the point of being insatiable. You can now consume 1 additional portion safely. Additionally, for 1 minute when you consume a portion, you have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB}, on attack rolls made as part of a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Occultist Guild
entries: {@i Hunt Mages and Magical Adversaries}

In Etharis, there are those who fear magic, and those who seek to understand it. Monster Hunters from the Occultist Guild know folk from both sides are equally dangerous. An Occultist investigates the arcane, the supernatural, and the uncanny, while avoiding the influence of superstition or ideology. Despite their reputation as mage hunters, Occultists don't burn their enemies at the stake—Occultists put them to the sword, as that's what swords are for. Knowledge and magic give Occultists an edge over their mystical adversaries. Their spells are used to detect and defend against dangerous arcana, and, above all, magic is used to destroy monsters that can't be harmed by steel.

subclassFeature.name: Acolyte of the Occult
entries: You gain proficiency in the {@skill Arcana|XPHB} skill.

subclassFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: Your study of the occult gives you the ability to cast spells.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: You learn two cantrips of your choice from the Wizard spell list. Whenever you gain a Monster Hunter level, you can replace one of these cantrips with another of your choice from the Wizard spell list.
When you reach Monster Hunter level 10, you learn another Wizard cantrip of your choice.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Occultist Spellcasting table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your level 1+ spells. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Prepared Spells of Level 1+
entries: You prepare the list of level 1+ spells that are available for you to cast with this feature. To start, choose three level 1 Wizard spells. {@spell Burning Hands|XPHB}, {@spell Detect Magic|XPHB}, and {@spell Protection from Evil and Good|XPHB} are recommended.

The number of spells on your list increases as you gain Monster Hunter levels, as shown in the Prepared Spells column of the Occultist Spellcasting table. Whenever that number increases, choose additional spells from the Wizard spell list until the number of spells on your list matches the number on the table. The chosen spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For example, if you're a level 7 Monster Hunter, your list of prepared spells can include five Wizard spells of levels 1 and 2 in any combination.

entries.name: Changing Your Prepared Spells
entries: Whenever you gain a Monster Hunter level, you can replace one spell on your list with another Wizard spell.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for your Wizard spells.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use an Arcane Focus as {@variantrule Spellcasting Focus|XPHB} for your Wizard spells.

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Interference
entries: You have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws against spells cast by creature types in your Monster Grimoire. Additionally, when a creature you can see within 60 feet of you casts a spell or makes a spell attack, you can use Studied Response against that creature before the spell is cast.

subclassFeature.name: Mage Hunter
entries: You consider Humanoids that can cast spells as being a creature type in your Monster Grimoire.

Additionally, when you damage a creature type in your Monster Grimoire that is {@status Concentration|XPHB|Concentrating}, it has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on the saving throw it makes to maintain its {@status Concentration|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Occult Knowledge
entries: Your knowledge of magic has increased so that you learn to cast Rituals. You can cast any spell as a {@variantrule Ritual|XPHB} if that spell has the {@variantrule Ritual|XPHB} tag and it's a spell you have prepared.

In addition, you learn two spells of your choice. These spells can come from the Cleric, Druid, or Wizard spell list or any combination thereof (see a class's section for its spell list). A spell you choose must have the {@variantrule Ritual|XPHB} tag.

When you reach Monster Hunter level 14, you can replace one of the spells you know from this feature with another spell of your choice from any spell list. The new spell must have the {@variantrule Ritual|XPHB} tag.

subclassFeature.name: Magical Aegis
entries: You gain the ability to extend a protective charm. You radiate an unseeable aura in a 20-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} that originates from you. The aura is inactive while you have the {@condition Incapacitated|XPHB} condition. You and allies in your aura have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws against spells cast by creature types in your Monster Grimoire.

Additionally, you always have the {@spell Counterspell|XPHB} spell prepared. You can cast {@spell Counterspell|XPHB} once without expending a spell slot. Once you cast the spell with this feature, you can't do so in this way again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Response
entries: You have learned to anticipate your enemies well enough to rapidly cast spells in response to their attacks. When you use Studied Response, you can cast a spell. The spell must have a casting time of an action and must target only that creature.

subclassFeature.name: Trapper Guild
entries: {@i Dispatch Monsters with Cunning Traps}

Legends say that the founding members of the Trapper Guild were game hunters who had grown bored of stalking common elk and dreamed of taking down bigger game. Trappers take pride in their kills and the ingenuity exhibited when a trap works perfectly.

The legacy of the Trapper Guild is a consistent testament to the benefits of lying in wait. The element of surprise is paramount to the trapper, whose kit can flourish before the hunter and monster even meet. Preparation is key, and the resourceful trapper has devices to assist in bringing down even the strongest foes.

subclassFeature.name: Sneaky and Crafty
entries: You gain proficiency in the {@skill Stealth|XPHB} skill and with {@item Tinker's Tools|XPHB}.

subclassFeature.name: Trapper Gadgets
entries: You learn to create gadgets and mechanisms that help you during the hunt.

As part of a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, you can craft two Trapper Gadgets if you have materials and {@item Tinker's Tools|XPHB} on hand. Also, with 1 hour of work with such a kit and expending 20 GP worth of materials (such as equipment or monster salvage), you can create one Trapper Gadget from the list below.
Some Trapper Gadgets allow your target to make an ability check or saving throw to resist the gadget's effects. The saving throw DC is calculated as follows:

subclassFeature.name: Ambusher's Advantage
entries: You have become a ferocious ambusher. When you roll {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB}, you can add your Intelligence modifier to the roll. Additionally, you can't be {@status surprised|XPHB} by enemies that inlcude creature types in your Monster Grimoire.

subclassFeature.name: Agile Response
entries: You can leap aside to avoid enemies rushing toward you. When a creature makes a melee attack roll against you, you can take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to impose {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on that roll and use your Studied Response as part of the same {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB}. Whether the attack hits or misses, you can then move up to half your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB}. This movement doesn't provoke {@action Opportunity Attack|XPHB|Opportunity Attacks}.

subclassFeature.name: Monster-Hide Armor
entries: You have learned to craft a set of Light or Medium armor by using dragon scales, werewolf hide, troll leather, or a similar monster component. The armor takes on the appearance of your choice, reflecting the component it is made from.

The armor has the same properties as Light or Medium armor (your choice when the armor is crafted) and gains two modifications from the Armor Modifications list. Whenever you gain a Monster Hunter level, you can replace one of these modifications with another modification.
Modifications require the armor to be worn to function.

subclassFeature.name: Rapid Tinkerer
entries: You have become capable of crafting trapper tools at a much faster rate. You can spend 1 minute to make a Trapper Gadget without spending GP or components.
You can use this feature twice, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Forgery Kit|XPHB}, {@item Book|XPHB} (history), {@item Magnifying Glass|XPHB}, {@item Parchment|XPHB} (10 sheets), {@item Robe|XPHB}, 8 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries: You've used your education and knowledge from working on behalf of the Augustine Trading Company. You've been generally held in high regard by those who can use the knowledge you've gained, while others look upon your work for the organization as unsavory. Your training, however, makes you a versatile problem-solver.

You've learned your craft from smugglers, merchants, blackmailers, and brigands who came before you. You may still work for the organization, or your may have had to cut ties for being too honest, too dishonest, or just in the wrong place at the wrong time. Whatever your connections, you have traveled more than most people in Etharis can ever dream of.

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Dagger|XPHB}, {@item Spear|XPHB}, {@item Leatherworker's Tools|XPHB}, {@item Hunting Trap|XPHB}, {@item Traveler's Clothes|XPHB}, 5 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries: You make your living by trapping, hunting, and killing vicious beasts. Your efforts might provide meat and furs for settlements or for trade. When a nearby beast is particularly vicious, you become a community's best defense against the destruction wildlife can cause.

While you hunt mundane beasts, you know there are more dangerous and supernatural creatures roaming the darkness. You and your fellow hunters are often as brutish as the creatures you hunt, heavily scarred from close encounters with your prey. In order to take down your prey, you must think and react as they might.

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Dagger|XPHB}, {@item Disguise Kit|XPHB}, {@item Robe|XPHB}, 12 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries: Many who fall on hard times have no other option than begging for coppers. Considered the lowest rung of society, you are looked down upon by other members of society, when they bother to notice you at all.

If you are from a major metropolis of Etharis, you might be much more than you appear. You may act as an informant, spy, distraction, or worseworking right under the noses of those who treat you as part of the scenery. This might make you wealthier than you let on, and people in the know treat you with a modicum of respect and caution.

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Dagger|XPHB}, {@item Tinker's Tools|XPHB}, Ancient Maps, {@item Parchment|XPHB} (10 sheets), {@item Robe|XPHB}, 8 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries: You are fascinated with studying history and identifying ancient artifacts, relics, and texts. You seek to gather rare and lost items to add to your collection or the collections of others.

Your skill with identifying the properties of artifacts and historical objects makes you an adept problem-solver, especially when ancient relics and languages are involved. Funding expeditions to search for these artifacts is often expensive, meaning you seldom travel without the backing of a wealthy patron or organization. These groups, like the Antiquarians they fund, have motives that range from the beneficent to the sinister. If you diverge from the intended goals of your benefactors, you might find yourself unfunded at best and hunted at worst.

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Dagger|XPHB}, {@item Shield|XPHB}, {@item Musical Instrument|XPHB} (same as above), {@item Traveler's Clothes|XPHB}, 6 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries: Knights of the Charneault Kingdom are more than soldiers. You're an exemplar of the virtues that maintain peace and prosperity in the realm. Through training and study, you've dedicated your life to upholding noble ideals such as strength, bravery, charity, temperance, and tradition.
You shoulder as a coat of arms your commitments to which you're swornthose of your household or Knight Chapter. If you are still a squire, yet to accomplish your first quest, your shield is blank.

You might receive many honors during your journeys, though much will be expected of you. Folk may look to you as a protector, leader, or keeper of traditionsor you may be feared as a stern justiciar of the Crown's justice. The path of a knight is difficult and perilous, and not all who walk it maintain their virtues.

items.name: Tool Proficiencies:
items.entry: One kind of {@item Musical Instrument|XPHB} or {@item Artisan's Tools|XPHB}

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Musical Instrument|XPHB} or {@item Artisan's Tools|XPHB} (same as above), Family Heirloom, {@item Fine Clothes|XPHB}, 15 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries: You were either born into a role within the courts or power structures of your area, or you worked your way into the company of the powerful or elite through perseverance, skill, trickery, or some combination of those. You draw upon the power of your institutions to gain what you needbut you're always at the mercy of those institutions as well.

You may have a specialized role within the system, such as a court jester or someone with influence. Or you may occupy a more generic role as a hanger-on, whose role is undefined but whose power rests simply in being connected to someone with the power to get what is needed.

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Spear|XPHB}, {@item Navigator's Tools|XPHB}, {@item Traveler's Clothes|XPHB}, Dilapidated Rowboat, 8 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries: You were a raider associated with one of the greatly feared Vaikan clans. The terror you and your allies struck within sailing distance of your homeland was massive and palpable. The risks were great, but the respect was undeniable.

You lost that respect, however, when something went wrong. Perhaps you lost your nerve and fled the battlefield. Perhaps you lost your mind and killed when you were only supposed to capture. Perhaps you saw the terror you inspired in others as a moral failing rather than a point of honor. Regardless, you were cast out of your clan and could never return. You now travel Etharis having to live with what you've done and the shame (or honor) of your clan's shunning.

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Dagger|XPHB}, {@item Calligrapher's Supplies|XPHB}, Diplomatic Papers, {@item Fine Clothes|XPHB}, {@item Signet Ring|XPHB}, 10 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries: You are the official representative of a government or other powerful group, traveling to further the objectives of the group you represent. You must be ready at a moment's notice to travel to the next town, or to other parts of the world. Such travel requires not just social skills but also a strong drive and a hardy disposition.

Your responsibilities change based on the organization you represent and their goals: forge alliances or maintain existing ones, establish business ties, oversee far-ranging projects, etc. However, many of your tasks are reactive: responding to a noble's threats, securing defensive pacts in times of conflict, or bolstering border defenses. Everywhere you go, something is at stake.

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Dagger|XPHB}, {@item Smith's Tools|XPHB}, Someone Else's Journal, {@item Traveler's Clothes|XPHB}, 10 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries: You were employed as an executioner by some group or organization in a position of power. Your legally sanctioned murders have given you a strong arm and a knowledge of death and fatal blows.

You may have worked for the Crimson Court, dispatching those who work against the nobility (if their blood is not worth draining). You may have worked for the Arcanist Inquisition, putting unrepentant mages to death. You may have carried out sanctioned sacrifices for the Prismatic Circle.

For some reason, you left your career: maybe you were wracked by guilt, maybe the group you worked for fell out of power, maybe you displeased your bosses, or maybe you decided to move on to a different occupation. But your actions have stayed with you, and your time as a dealer of death have made a lasting impact.

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Dagger|XPHB}, {@item Navigator's Tools|XPHB}, Maps, {@item Traveler's Clothes|XPHB}, 8 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries: You pursue a life traversing the wilds, driven by wanderlust or the orders of a distant patron. For you, there is no greater pursuit than to discover the lost, forgotten, and unseen reaches of the world.
You may travel unaccompanied or lead companions, establishing encampments in remote areas or living completely off the land. You might lead pioneers looking to settle uncharted lands.

You may help establish settlements in the areas you explore, but before long, your attention wanders, and the call of the unknown beckons too strongly to ignore. And when that happens, you blaze a new trail into the darkness, rushing headlong into whatever thrills await.

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Dagger|XPHB}, {@item Poisoner's Kit|XPHB}, {@item Hunting Trap|XPHB}, {@item Traveler's Clothes|XPHB}, 8 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries: Etharis is overrun with vermin, but for you those pests of the four-legged variety. In the cities these are generally rats and other rodents. In the country, the pests might come in the form of raccoons or other critters that steal food and destroy structures piece by piece.

You've trained in the arts of getting pests away from people and coin away from clients. You may run an honest business, helping farmers and shop owners eliminate potentially life-threatening pests. Or you may introduce those pests in the first place, then solve the problem you created, skipping town before your ploy is discovered.

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Dagger|XPHB}, {@item Musical Instrument|XPHB} (same as above), {@item Traveler's Clothes|XPHB}, 8 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries: The powerful and fickle faerie-folk of your area have taken note of you, and your existence pleases them. Whether you were born under a lucky star, had a favorable run-in with a nature spirit, or simply were in the right place at the right time, the fey favor you with small gifts and boons. You find small trinkets in your shoes when you wake up in the morning. Beasts of the forest and field are more receptive to your presence and your training. Will this blessing somehow turn into a curse later in your life?

People you encounter instantly recognize your connection with the Realm of Faerie. Sometimes this works to your favor, as folks seem entranced by your glowing personality. Other times your power is a curse just waiting to seep into their lives. And they may not be wrong!

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Dagger|XPHB}, {@item Spear|XPHB}, {@item Gaming Set|XPHB} (same as above), {@item Robe|XPHB}, 10 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries: Mud, blood, and coin have been your entire life since joining the Company of Free Swords. You may have been recruited from a fighting pit in Unterland, joined as a fugitive to escape justice, or been found as a babe in the mud and raised as a Free Sword. Your history before joining the Company doesn't matter now. Your comrades are your family. Violence is your trade.

The infantry ranks of the Free Swords live by the unspoken rule of Etharisit's a place where only the strong survive. Your ambitions may stretch only as far as your payment for enduring the next battle. Few expect anything more from you. Yet a hidden ideal may truly drive your actions, or you may hope to lead your own company one day.

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Disguise Kit|XPHB}, Heretical Text, {@item Holy Symbol|XPHB}, {@item Traveler's Clothes|XPHB}, 10 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries: You have learned that the dominant religious beliefs of your region are lies. The corrupting forces may be in charge, but you will not rest until you have shown their lies as corrupt and untrue. Your beliefs, and your willingness to speak that truth, have put you in danger from the authorities.

You travel the road or live in hiding, trying to stay one step ahead of those who wish to silence you. You sometimes find those who believe as you do, and in those moments of unity you find peace and safety. But it is only a matter of time before your outspoken opposition to the status quo puts you in danger again.

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Club|XPHB}, {@item Navigator's Tools|XPHB}, Book Containing Holy Rites, {@item Holy Symbol|XPHB}, Interrogator's Tools, {@item Manacles|XPHB}, {@item Traveler's Clothes|XPHB}, 10 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries: You are a servant of the Watchers of the Faithful, hunting down heretics and blasphemers within your own faith, cultists of sinister powers, or other threats to your divine order.
Divine justice does not discriminate, and you have mercilessly punished crimes both mundane and supernaturaltasks that leave scars both on body and soul.

You travel far and wide in your role, spreading the rumors of the sinful and the deviant take you. Corruption is just as likely to fester within as without, so you must be ever watchful of those who travel with you. Those found guilty, wherever they hail from and for whatever their reason, must be faced without mercy.

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Club|XPHB}, {@item Navigator's Tools|XPHB}, {@item Disguise Kit|XPHB}, {@item Traveler's Clothes|XPHB}, 8 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries: You spent years traveling the countryside as a member of the Arcanist Inquisition, seeking out heretics and blasphemers, daemons and arcanists. Your work uncovered hidden evil that likely saved the lives of countless innocents. However, on more than one occasion, your or others' zeal brought low innocents.

After a crisis of conscience, you left the ranks of the inquisitors. Leaving the Inquisition is itself a dangerous prospect, but you could no longer abide. Maybe someone you love and care for was accused falsely or maybe arcane affinities would have led to their destruction. Maybe you are that accused person. Maybe the last investigation you carried out opened your eyes to new realities. Now you are living with a target on your back. Your former peers don't take kindly to people leaving their ranks. Those you persecuted have not forgotten your deeds. But life must still be lived, and there's more than one way to find and destroy the evil in the world.

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Woodcarver's Tools|XPHB}, {@item Herbalism Kit|XPHB}, {@item Traveler's Clothes|XPHB}, 8 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries: On the fringes of the civilized world, parents warn their children not to wander away from their homes, especially at night. The many creatures that haunt the forests, from the faerie-folk to the minions of the Great Beast, spell doom for the innocent who stray too far into the darkness. You failed to heed your parents' warnings, and you were taken. In fact, those who know of your experience use that word to describe you: Taken.

You do not remember what happened to you while you were away, but through some mysterious and possibly fortunate circumstances, you wandered back into town after months or years of going missing. Maybe the fairies whisked you off to some magical realm. Maybe evil cultists of an Arch Daemon held you prisoner, planning to sacrifice you to their dark leader when the time was right, and you found a way to escape. Maybe one of the Beast's warped and feral minions took a liking to you and kept you as a pet. Whatever your story, you can't remember your time away. But that doesn't mean you weren't changed by it.

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Dagger|XPHB} (scalpel), {@item Healer's Kit|XPHB}, {@item Herbalism Kit|XPHB}, Bandages, Book of Remedies, Jar of Leeches, {@item Robe|XPHB}, 10 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries: Your skills treating the sick and injured have given you a vast knowledge of illnesses and remedies based on the latest scienceor the most recent theories from those who like to push the limits of what science might allow.

You may have come into the field in a variety of ways and with a variety of specialties. You might have learned at an institute with the finest medical minds in all of Etharis. Or you might have learned your skills through trial and error, as the poor residents of the surrounding area come to you based on rumors of your preternatural healing powers that are rather mundane.

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Dagger|XPHB}, {@item Carpenter's Tools|XPHB} or {@item Mason's Tools|XPHB} (same as above), Mule and Cart, {@item Traveler's Clothes|XPHB}, 8 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries: There is still land in Etharis where no one has lived before, and pioneers are the hardy folk who set out to tame that land for the first time. You've learned to find a suitable area to live, set up the beginnings of a village, build the dwellings needed for settlers, then move on.

You have weathered punishing storms, migrations, and harsh winters. You and yours have adapted to the environment. Everything you own is built with your own two hands, and your aptitude in working with natural materials has provided you with shelter, tools, and clothing.

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Dagger|XPHB}, {@item Spear|XPHB}, {@item Gaming Set|XPHB} (same as above), {@item Robe|XPHB}, 10 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries: Pit fighting was once a major institution in the Brach Empire. Since then, the practice has been driven underground, but, like poison spreading silently throughout a healthy body, it has infiltrated nearly every major city.

Ostensibly illegal, you can almost always find small groups of desperate individuals putting their lives on the line for the amusement and enrichment of others. This hidden network of arenas has recently been organized into the self-proclaimed Pit Fighter's Guild and developed a series of coded phrases and symbols to identify its members. You follow the unspoken rule of Etharis: only the strong survive.

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Herbalism Kit|XPHB}, {@item Traveler's Clothes|XPHB}, 8 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries: When you fell ill with the Weeping Pox, you assumed you would die from it, as had so many before you. Your neighbors shunned you, fearing that you would spread the disease to them and their families. Then a miracle happened. A stranger came to you and offered to help. The stranger brought forth strange medicines, providing you with curative draughts and elixirs. And just as the disease reached its worst stages, the symptoms began to vanish. Before long, you were cured of the disease.

The sores and scars of the disease, however, still display across your bodyan unsubtle reminder of the terrible scourge you survived. The stranger left you after the treatments concluded, but you retained some of the knowledge that the healer used while caring for you. Those who marvel at your recovery also fear you: they harbor suspicion that you made deals with dark powers to drive away the disease.

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Dagger|XPHB} (shiv), {@item Thieves' Tools|XPHB}, {@item Traveler's Clothes|XPHB}, 8 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries: Something from your past landed you in prison. Your transgressions might be real or imagined, against a just society or a corrupt one. Regardless of how you became a prisoner, you have learned to survive within your environment.

As a prisoner, you've had to learn to deal with guards, other prisoners, and the unpleasant environment. Part of that survival was learning to find, craft, or steal small items that make your incarceration more tolerable. Whether your release was long ago or about to happen, your time as a Prisoner has changed you.

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Dagger|XPHB}, {@item Artisan's Tools|XPHB}, Bag of Trinkets from Travels, {@item Traveler's Clothes|XPHB}, 8 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries: Valikan raiders search for many things: food, goods, weapons, and thralls. You were one of those taken by the clans because you had skills that the clan lacked in their cold northern home. Once you arrived, you were given a choice: join the clan or find your own way home. You chose the latter. You then had to find your way through the cold and dangerous lands of Valikaand whatever other lands separated you from your home.
You had to be ever watchful of other threats, hiding when danger presented itself. No place is safe, and you must take every opportunity to advance toward your goals.

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Cartographer's Tools|XPHB}, {@item Ink Pen|XPHB}, {@item Parchment|XPHB}, {@item Robe|XPHB}, 8 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries: You served a mysterious organization simply called the Thaumaturge. You received orders to perform tasks that ranged from the mundane to the inscrutable. Your contact assured you that even if the tasks made no sense, you were serving the greater good of your home, and of all Etharis.

Your tasks led you to new locations. You secretly met with other members of the organization, and you looked to the stars to give you signs and portents about the future. You may still be performing these tasks, or years may have passed since your last contact, but you know that there are forces beyond understanding that pull on people's strings and make them dance.

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Forgery Kit|XPHB}, Chest (with False Bottom), {@item Parchment|XPHB}, {@item Costume|XPHB}, 8 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries: Goods from one side of Etharis often fetch a fair price on the other side. Transporting such goods are a hassledealing with the bureaucracy of customs and taxes is an even larger one. Thankfully, as a representative of the Ebon Syndicate, you are there to eliminate at least part of the hassle.

Whether you move goods by land, sea, river, or air, crossing borders and avoiding detection are your specialty. Sometimes having a way to hide goods is the game. Other times falsifying paperwork or bribing guards does the trick. However you manage to do it, you get what people want into their hands for the right price.

monster.name: Fleshling Construct
languages: understands the languages known by the target

action.name: Strangle
entries: {@atkr m} {@hitYourSpellAttack Bonus equals your spell attack modifier}, reach 5 ft. {@h}{@damage 2d8 + summonSpellLevel} Bludgeoning damage, and the target has the {@condition Grappled|XPHB} condition (escape DC equals your spell save DC) and can't speak. Until the grapple ends, the target has the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition and is {@hazard Suffocation|XPHB|suffocating}.

action.name: Constrict
entries: The fleshling construct constricts a target that it is grappling, doing {@damage 2d8 + summonSpellLevel} Bludgeoning damage.

hp.special: 6 plus six times your Barbarian level (the beast has {@variantrule Hit Point Dice|XPHB|Hit Dice} [d10s] equal to your Barbarian level)

trait.name: Protective Instinct
entries: When the guardian becomes {@variantrule Bloodied|XPHB}, it gains {@variantrule Temporary Hit Points|XPHB} equal to half of its maximum {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} and is enraged for 10 minutes. While enraged, {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} creatures within 5 feet have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on attack rolls against creatures other than the guardian.

trait.name: Vigilant
entries: The guardian can't be {@status surprised|XPHB}.

trait.name: Wild Bond
entries: Add your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus} to any ability check, attack roll, or saving throw the beast makes.

action.name: Natural Weapon
entries: {@atkr m} Bonus equals your attack modifier using Strength, reach 5 ft. {@h}{@dice 1d4 + 2} plus your Rage Damage bonus Bludgeoning, Piercing, or Slashing damage (your choice when you summon the beast).

reaction.name: Body Block
entries: {@actTrigger} When a creature the beast can see attacks a target other than itself that is within 5 feet of it. {@actResponse} The guardian takes the damage instead of the target.

hp.special: 5 plus four times your Barbarian level (the beast has {@variantrule Hit Point Dice|XPHB|Hit Dice} [d6s] equal to your Barbarian level)

trait.name: Aquatic Assault (Sea Only)
entries: While the beast is submerged in water, it has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on attack rolls against creatures without a {@variantrule Swim Speed|XPHB} submerged in water.

trait.name: Enraged Strikes
entries: While your Rage is active, the beast's attack rolls have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB}.

trait.name: Flyby (Sky Only)
entries: The beast doesn't provoke {@action Opportunity Attack|XPHB|Opportunity Attacks} when it flies out of an enemy's reach.

trait.name: Wild Bond
entries: Add your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus} to any ability check, attack roll, or saving throw the beast makes.

action.name: Natural Weapon
entries: {@atkr m} Bonus equals your attack modifier using Strength, reach 5 ft. {@h}{@dice 1d8 + 2} plus your Rage Damage bonus Bludgeoning, Piercing, or Slashing damage (your choice when you summon the beast).

reaction.name: Harry (Land Only)
entries: {@actTrigger} When a creature the beast can see within 5 feet of it makes an attack roll. {@actResponse} The triggering attack roll has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB}.

trait.name: Three Heads
entries: The gasdra has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) checks and on saving throws to avoid or end the {@condition Blinded|XPHB}, {@condition Charmed|XPHB}, {@condition Deafened|XPHB}, {@condition Frightened|XPHB}, {@condition Stunned|XPHB}, or {@condition Unconscious|XPHB} conditions. The gasdra can take one {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} for each of its heads. The extra {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB|Reactions} can be used only for {@action Opportunity Attack|XPHB|Opportunity Attacks}.

trait.name: Wakeful
entries: While the gasdra sleeps, at least one of its heads is awake.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The gasdra makes three Beak attacks.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atkr m} {@hit 4}, reach 5 ft. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) Bludgeoning damage.

hp.special: 5 + 10 per spell level (the swarm has Hit Dice [d8s] equal to the spell's level)

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The swarm has {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of the swarm's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally doesn't have the {@condition Incapacitated|XPHB} condition.

trait.name: Swarm
entries: The swarm can enter and occupy the space of another creature and vice versa, and the swarm can move through any opening large enough for a Tiny Beast.

action.name: Bites
entries: {@atkr m} {@hitYourSpellAttack Bonus equals your spell attack modifier}, reach 0 ft. {@h}{@damage 2d6 + 1 + summonSpellLevel} Piercing damage.

hp.special: 20 (Blooming and Thorny Only) or 30 (Oaken Only) + 10 for each spell level above 2

trait.name: Sylvan Regeneration
entries: The spirit regains 1 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB|Hit Point} at the start of its turn if it has at least 1 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB|Hit Point} and is in direct sunlight.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The plant makes a number of attacks equal to half this spell's level (rounded down).

action.name: Petal Burst (Blooming Only)
entries: The plant causes a burst of petals to fill the air within a 10-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation}. The area is {@variantrule Heavily Obscured|XPHB} for 1 minute.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atkr m} {@hitYourSpellAttack Bonus equals your spell attack modifier}, reach 5 ft. {@h}{@damage 1d8 + 3 + summonSpellLevel} Bludgeoning or Piercing damage (Thorny Only).

reaction.name: Oaken Shield (Oaken Only)
entries: When a creature within 5 feet of the plant takes damage from an attack, the plant takes the damage instead.

reaction.name: Prickly Protection (Thorny Only)
entries: When a creature within 5 feet of the plant attacks it, the plant makes a Slam attack with {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} against the creature.

trait.name: Flyby (Scaled Wings only)
entries: The sea serpent doesn't provoke {@action Opportunity Attack|XPHB|Opportunity Attacks} when it flies out of an enemy's reach.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The sea serpent makes a number of attacks equal to half this spell's level (rounded down).

action.name: Allure (Glowing Lantern only)
entries: The sea serpent causes a lantern hanging from one of its fins to glow eerily. {@actSave wis} DC equals your spell save DC, each creature in a 30-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} originating from the sea serpent. {@actSaveFail} The target is {@condition Charmed|XPHB} by the sea serpent until the start of its next turn. Creatures have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on the saving throw if the sea serpent has dealt damage to them already this turn, and the {@condition Charmed|XPHB} condition ends immediately if the sea serpent deals damage to a creature {@condition Charmed|XPHB} by this ability.

action.name: Inhale (Enormous Mouth only)
entries: {@actSave str} DC equals your spell save DC, each creature in a 15-foot {@variantrule Cone [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Cone}. {@actSaveFail} {@damage 1d6 + summonSpellLevel} Psychic damage and the creature is pulled 5 feet straight toward it or, if the creature is already within 5 feet of the sea serpent, it takes an additional {@damage 2d6} Piercing damage. {@actSaveSuccess} Half damage.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atkr m} {@hitYourSpellAttack Bonus equals your spell attack modifier}, reach 5 ft. {@h}{@damage 1d6 + 3 + summonSpellLevel} Piercing damage and the creature has the {@condition Grappled|XPHB} condition (escape DC equals your spell save DC). The {@condition Grappled|XPHB} condition ends if the sea serpent bites a different creature.

action.name: Thrash
entries: {@atkr m} {@hitYourSpellAttack Bonus equals your spell attack modifier}, reach 10 ft. {@h}{@damage 1d10 + 3 + summonSpellLevel} Bludgeoning damage and the target is pushed 5 feet away from the sea serpent.

spell.name: Arboreal Curse
entries: You attempt to turn one creature that you can see within range into wood. The creature makes a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, it has the {@condition Restrained|XPHB} condition as its flesh begins to harden into bark. On a successful save, its {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} is 0 until the start of your next turn.

A creature {@condition Restrained|XPHB} by this spell makes a Constitution saving throw at the end of each of its turns. If it successfully saves three times, the condition ends. If it fails three times, it is turned into a tree and has the {@condition Petrified|XPHB} condition. The successes and failures needn't be consecutive; keep track of both until the target collects three of a kind.
If the creature is burned, chopped down, or otherwise destroyed while {@condition Petrified|XPHB}, it is killed.

A creature remains transformed unless the effect is reversed within 1 year with {@spell Greater Restoration|XPHB}, {@spell Wish|XPHB}, or similar magic. If the creature spends 1 year and 1 day as a tree, the transformation becomes permanent, and nothing can return the creature to its original form.

spell.name: Arcane Aegis
entries: When you cast this spell, you are surrounded by a shimmering light that quickly dissipates. You gain {@dice 2d10} {@variantrule Temporary Hit Points|XPHB}. If a creature hits you with a melee attack before the spell ends, the creature takes Force damage equal to the number of {@variantrule Temporary Hit Points|XPHB} lost as a result of the attack. The spell ends early if you have no {@variantrule Temporary Hit Points|XPHB}.

entriesHigherLevel.name: Using a Higher-Level Spell Slot
entries: You gain an additional {@dice 2d10} {@variantrule Temporary Hit Points|XPHB} for each spell slot level above 1.

spell.name: Assisted Aim
entries: You invigorate up to three creatures within range with improved accuracy. Each target gains a +1 bonus to attack rolls it makes with Ranged weapons. Additionally, the normal and long range of Ranged weapons wielded by a target are doubled for the spell's duration.

entriesHigherLevel.name: Using a Higher-Level Spell Slot
entries: You can target one additional creature for each spell slot level above 1.

spell.name: Binding Pledge

components.m: a book of religious or legal importance
